This is a mount to hold (2) laser-line diodes, a 9v battery, and micro on/off switch. It mounts on a plasma torch to project a set of cross-hairs onto the material surface to allow precise placement of the torch location before starting. The mount was designed to be placed on a Thermal Dynamics SL100 machine torch (1.4" diameter). There are 3 holes to accommodate #6 machine screws to allow tightening of the diodes and torch once the mount populated. The laser diodes can be found cheap on ebay/amazon. The holes are cut for 1/2" diameter. The hole for the micro switch is 1/4" diameter. Design is uploaded to TinkerCad (https://tinkercad.com/things/7t1o1756q7Z) in case you need to adjust the cut-outs for your particular torch.

This is a wing bolt for Bix3 R/C plane.  
Two of them are required to attach the main wing on top of the fuselage. Unfortunately they are easy to lose or to break and it would be a very bad idea to try flying without them ;-)

Printed with Prusa I3 Hephestos using black PLA. In Cura I set the following settings in "Support" section :
Support type : Touching buildplate
Platform adhesion type : Brim Once printed there was a bit of support material stuck to the bolt so I had to slightly sand it.

description.text:
After a certain national Windscreen replacement company replaced a cracked windscreen on my Toyota Avensis D4D Tourer (Estate) I noticed a lot of moisture in the engine compartment. I traced the problem back to the seal at the top of the bonnet where the seal had once been attached to the engine compartment it was now free to move to the incorrect positions. I can't blame the last guy to change my windscreen, as there was also glue on the seal where the guy before him had tried to disguise the fact he'd lost or broken some of the car's clips. So here's a photo. Bathrobotics. The original clip is the central and white one, the others are 3D printed ones (I was at the end of the Green Filament and just switched to Pink as no one will see these unless I post them online). They have been Acetone Vapour Bathed in a £10 coffee filter maker from PC WORLD. Bath Robotics aka EurIng Andy Southern has challenged myself to release 1 design to open source per day. I think I've lasted longer than on other New Years Resolutions. This is for 11th January 2015. These Clips fit Toyota but are not toyota parts. I do not claim them to been toyota. I do not use Toyota Logo. No Toyotas have been harmed in the making of this design. @ALSO CHECK OUT MY TOYOTA PARCEL SHELF CLIPS HERE:@
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:426125 No Rights reserved on this. description.text:
A cute little critter with a dark side. I needed a bit of a Voodoo doll for a problem I'm working though, and I don't knit... or practice Voodoo... so I fell back to the trust 'ole 3D printer.   
This little fella will happily take a left handed knifing between the shoulder blades, or a right hander under the ribs... or both. (knife included, batteries not required)  
If on the other hand you're feeling less approachable, you can arm your little penguin to warn others what may happen if they ask a silly question.  
There are also less psycho options, including a body with no holes for knife like implements, more sane eyes, and different length beaks (the medium one is the one in the pictures).

All items will print without support as all of the angles are about 45 degrees.  
The eyes will print flat as in the STL directly or on the flat edge if you want the grain to match the body. The same goes with the chest piece.  
Once the chest and eyes are glued in, the beaks are interchangeable... I did try to make a Perry the Platypuss style beak, but it didn't work for me :)

Raft and supports are highly recommended.
Assembly might be a little tight and may require the pins to be broken off and the legs to be glued in place instead.

description.text:
Designed for strength, function and light weight, build yourself this 230 size Quadcopter frame. http://youtu.be/-e-3kbXzwzk
http://youtu.be/jaZK9bDb17U
http://youtu.be/BU2Z-EG56js Suggested Setup:
-Motor: RacerStar 1806 2280kv or Racerstar 2204 2300KV
-ESC: ZTW Spider 18A BLHELI x 4, or Racerstar RS20Ax4 20A 4 in 1 (inbuilt PDB)
-Prop: 10 Pairs GEPRC 5040 V2 5 Inch 3 Blade Propeller -Flight Controller: F3 Pro with OSD,5vBEC,Current Sensor or F3 Flight Controller with OSD,5vBEC,Current Sensor, PDB -Battery: ZOP 3S 1100mah 65c or ZOP 4S 1100mah 65c
-LiPo Battery Charger:
iMAX B6 Digital RC Lipo Balance Charger
12V 5A AC Power Adapter
XT60 Connector to Banana Plug -Remote Control:
FlySky FS-i6 or
FrSky Taranis Transmitter and FrSky Receiver HDcam mounting strap slots compatible with Mobius, RunCam and GoPro. -Optional extras if you need them:
Lipo Battery Tie Down Strap
XT60 Male Female Plug Connector 12AWG 10cm Power Cable
Silicone Anti-vibration Pad in for 22XX Series Motor Updated
Base and Top v1.1 - rear mounting spacers moved further back for better rear arm support.
Added 22 size Motor Arm Enjoy this design? Consider supporting me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/Tech2C

All parts printed at 0.2mm layer height and 3 perimeters. -Top and Bottom frames, HDcam and FPVcam @ 30% infill x 1 of each
-Arms @ 100% infill x 4
-ArmSupport @ 100% infill x 2 Non-printed parts required:
-12 x M3x10mm countersunk screws for Top/Bottom frame (Amazon affiliate link)
-6 x M3x40mm Nylon Spacers for Top/Bottom frame (Amazon affiliate link)
-8 x M3x12mm countersunk screws for Arms (Amazon affiliate link)
-8 x M3 Nyloc nuts for Arms (Amazon affiliate link)
-3 x Vibration Ball Dampeners for HDcam

comments.text: Do you have your motors, battery, pdb (power distribution board), props, battery alarm, and receiver for your i6? If so, what are their specs? Basically, you want to have the FC (flight controller) wired to the PDB on the frame, then wire the receiver to the FC, and then the ESC servo leads wired to the FC. The ESCs should then be soldered to the PDB, and then the motor soldered to the ESCs. Next, after all of t he wiring is complete, configure the FC via software like Cleanflight or something like that. There are lots of resources at your local library probably which are very useful. Good luck with your build! Check out this image for clarification: http://www.rcdronegood.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/Naze-32-Connection-Diagram.jpg

comments.text:
Hello,
could you please so kind and explain me what is the difference between the F3 flight controller and the CC3D EVO?
comments.author: Tech2C

comments.text: The CC3D flight controller doesn't include an On Screen Display (OSD) which can be used to overlay information on the FPV live footage, such as battery voltage, receiver signal strength, artificial horizon, etc. It also doesn't have a Battery Eliminator Circuit (BEC) meaning you will need to supply 5volts to the electronics some other way. Also no Power Distribution Board (PDB) so you need to join the ESC and battery wires together some other way too.

Also, It could be great to see more setup suggestions (thank you Dave855).
For now, I've printed the arms with PETG, 45% infill, 3 shells and it seems rock solid with some flexibility.
I also tried HIPS, and the interesting point is that its super lightweight (but i don't know if HIPS properties get along with drones...).
comments.author: mediaklan

comments.text: Hi, I've ordered the parts for a quad and I am considering which frame I will print. This one seems a good option, thank you for the design. I have a question, if you mind.

comments.text: ABS @ 50% infill, it is very ridged. No worries.
comments.author: eshneto

comments.text:
Hi. The vertical thrust from each motor is about 400g using the recommended setup. The plastic arms have no problem maintaining their shape during thrust pumps. Where problems do occur is during an uncontrolled landing... :)
Cheers!
comments.author: eshneto

comments.text: Of course, thanks.

comments.text:
Hi,
I'm a newbie for the quadcopter hobby, I have plenty of other RC's. I'd really like to build this one but do you have more of a BOM for a recommended setup? I noticed the motors you're using are out of stock at the moment.
comments.author: JJCadMan

comments.text: Hi, you mention printing @ 0.2mm layer height with 3 perimeters, what would be the result if printed with 0.3mm layer height & same perimeters? Would the parts still all go together?
comments.author: wayneo

comments.text:
Yep 0.3mm should be fine. At 0.3mm the z layer height isn't divisible evenly with these parts, so your slicing program will either add or subtract 1 z layer.
Not a problem with this frame :)
comments.author: wayneo

comments.text: Are 250 arms possible on this frame, or would the body need to be extended then? Guess longer arms must be thicker to avoid flex/vibration.
comments.author: CodeChief

comments.text:
I could lengthen the arms to accommodate a 250 wheelbase, however I don't think 6inch props would fit, you'd still be stuck with 5inch props.
Most likely I'd have to tilt the rear arms back a touch, plus slightly longer arms all round would suffice for 6inch props. The front arms would have to stay the same angle to ensure the props aren't visible to FPV cameras.
comments.author: CodeChief

comments.text: Thanks for the quick reply. I guess the other option is to trim the props to "bullnose" them. I've seen a prop trimmer 3D model on here too I wanted to try. I'll give that a go :-)

comments.text: Fantastic results!  After putting together the Prusa-type 3D printer (a challenge in itself), I calibrated and made a few doodads just to get the settings right, then printed off all the Peon230 parts.  As you suggested, I used PLA and it worked like a charm.  I had pretty much all the hardware sitting around from other multi-rotor projects, so it was a snap to assemble the frame.  I haven't installed the motors, ESCs, APM, etc yet, but will get to that soon.  I have a standard APM 2.6 controller (my favorite), which is a bit large for this frame.  I will probably pick up a mini APM to use instead.  My only modification was to add four 20mm nylon spacers to the bottom to act as landing skids.  Excellent job designing this.  Tolerances are perfect, it fits together like a glove.  Many thanks!

That's great news Max!
You've gone from ordering a 3D printer kit to a fully assembled Peon230 frame - that is an achievement in itself.

comments.text: I am having some trouble printing the top.  It is printing as to be expected initially, then halfway through the print it offsets then entire model down and to the right by 5mm (down 5mm and right 5mm).  Anyone else having this problem?  I am printing on a newly built printrbot metal simple with heated bed and using 1.75mm PLA and Cura.  Any ideas on how to correct this?  Thanks!
comments.author: ThingFraser

comments.text: Check your belt tension, given that it's happening halfway though, check your stepper drivers and make sure they are not skipping steps. possibly slow down your printers travel speed to avoid it/increase current to driver
comments.author: ThingFraser

comments.text: Thanks for the response. I will do some investigating. I think it might be the PLA spool getting knotted and no allowing the Y-axis to travel appropriately. Thanks again. I can't wait to finish the build!
comments.author: kronikabis

comments.text: or it could be a gear slipping on the motor shaft....just loose enough to occasionally hang and loose steps like it was in my case ;) causing the whole print to shift position all at once about 2/3 rds of the way through a 13hr print is when i fixed mine, It would only slip occasionally though i guess as the singularities added up........ hope this helps

I have some questions, can you explain me which BECs are you using, and how did you make the fpv power filter?
thank you!
comments.author: Sanx

comments.text:
Hey Thx! The ESC's are 10A with inbuilt 1A BEC's plus SimonK firmware loaded.
The FPV power filter is just an L-C circuit. I wrap the positive wire through a toroid a dozen loops, plus a 1000uF capacitor in parallel with the positive and negative wires. Here's a useful link http://www.fpvuk.org/how-tos/lc-filters/

title: Transmitter mounted table holder for HP Stream 7

description.text:
Since I now have an APM on my camera quadcopter, I got a Windows 8.1 tablet for mission planner. Holding it in one hand isn't smart, so I came up with this.
There's an opening on the left side to attach an OTG cable, i.e. for the 3DR Radio.
The bottom has a hole to fit a 1/4"/20 camera thread insert. I actually cracked apart a Mobius holding base to get it, and used a hot soldering iron to melt it into the hole.
The mount on the transmitter is a generic monitor mount that you can find on ebay.
Printed in PLA, 40% infill, sliced with Slic3r. It just fits on a 200mm wide printing bed.

comments.text: What about the USB transmitter that connects Mission Planner to the APM? Does this tablet have a USB port? If not, how are you making it communicate with the APM flight controller?

title: Clock Face For PVC Double Faced Clock

description.text: This is a clock face inspired by AndrewStaroscik's Two-Color Clock Face, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43815 , and designed to work in a clock like Make Magazines' http://blog.makezine.com/projects/pvc-two-faced-clock/ which is a current father /daughter project.

I need all the help I can get with CAD and printing-- so I leave the deatails to you. For some reason, my circle is really a polygon with about 25 sides rather than a true circle. I presume I am doing something incorrectly in Sketchup. (BTW, I found the answer to the polygon issue here:
https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups=#!topic/sketchuphowto/B7AYR-fBhKE
-but it looks like I would have to start from scratch to get more of a "circle" ). Anyway, print out starting with background color. When the numerals start, pause and switch to a different color of your choice. My first print (the one pictured) came out rough when it got the the numerals-- so your retraction and infill settings hopefully is fine tuned in better than mine. A clock movement like this should work: http://www.klockit.com/products/dept-157__sku-AAAVV.html

title: Dual cup holder / carrier -20M Filament Medium Fill-

description.text:
This is my first make, so go easy please. I made this because I would always run out and get food. I would have a hard time carrying the bag and the 2 drinks I always got. So I made this. It holds 2 drinks of many sizes from different places. You put the 2 drinks in, and carry it around by the handle. It works on either side.  
So far I have tried medium chick-fil-a cups, red solo cups, household cups. Basically any normal cup that is small on the bottom and gets bigger as you get to the top.  
It uses around 20M filament on medium fill with 0.2 thickness. No support needed.  
Disclaimer: Not all cups will fit, use at your own risk with any glass bottles/cups. It will fit many cups, but not all.
Print and put the cups in the holes and hold by the circular handle.

This is universal spool roller unit & stand.
It uses 608zz bearings, no bolts and nuts are required to assemble. Roller parts is 12cm long which should be fit for most of filament bobbin, I hope. If you want to use roller units different ways, you can design a stand of your own to meet your requirement. Instead of using two,only one roller-unit can be mounted on frame of 'prusa i3' style printer centering a hole of bobbin, if you design stand properly.

• Push pin through hole of bearing and snap-in to the roller holder. You might need little force to do it. (Do not try assemble pin to holder without bearing, it might not be pulled out.)

  • Make 3 more.

  • Screw each into roller.

  • Insert roller units to stand.

title: Firefighting Drone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Hollow armed drone 2 fight fires in swarm.

bushfires and chemical fires are hard to extinguish. we humans are usually too low in numbers to effectively fight such fires. airplanes go down because of hot-cold-air zones. with painfull loss of the pilots and the costly plane. helicopters are no picknick either.... they have to haul water underneath, as a big weight, wich steers the heli.
So i decided that's a too dangerous strategy to extinguish fires..
i started thinking about tanker trucks, wich have bulkheads in the tanks, to reduce the braking weight.
apply the same logic to a water-filled drone arm, of wich u need at least 4 to fly.
u have now 4 tanker-truck-derived drone arms in your head,
Existing drone designs prove folding is an option.
so large scale printing, and towing it behind a firetruck is an option too. So far, we have a neat drone design.
but too extinguish a big fire, u need a lot of water... and flying one drone time after time.. could be quite useless... even if they are bigscale. So thats the point where i introduced triangulation. the tech used to make some drones follow your phone? well, that's arduino programmable, ... so everythings possible... started a year ago,, printed three prototypes allready.
none of them float enough to lift back up after landing on water and filling itself up :( Prototype 4 has hollow drone-arm walls as floats...
i will post pics as soon as i have a prototype that actually does what its supposed too :)

the arms are printed vertically, not horizontally.. they r round cause teardrop and oval designs caused turbulence under the drone. Don't know exactly why. guessing counterrotating props have something to do with it.
-SLicer will support too much. i suggest dual head and soluble support.
-cura 's 'touch bed' will support only the mounts.
PS this design sinks as a rock when filled up, do not test it ;)

description.text: I made this box with lid to hold the contacts of the hot bed for the cables with a cable

This little handy tool is made to screw nuts on metric rods, you can scale it up for any metric sized nut+rod. Just scale it by the factor equal to your rod diameter.
So for fastening a M4 nut you need to scale it by x4 ,for a M6 nut scale it byy x6 and so on.
The hole in the handle is made so that you can screw the nut to any position on the rod, most tools either can fall off the nut while turning it (like a wrench) or can only screw the nut to a certain distance on the rod, like a torque wrench.
Please give me feedback on the fitting of this tool as i didnt test it for every size so far.

description.text: I purchased a laptop style power adapter for my rostock-mini from 321-short-circuit on ebay. It came with a power inlet jack. comments.text: Overall it fits my Banana Pro and is a well thought out design, thanks for sharing it.  Some notes on the model as of January 2015 - I couldn't get the audio port into the audio port opening of the case without trimming some of the case opening, since the round opening isn't split in the middle the hole is partially enclosed.  The slot for the micro-sd card is very tight, little margin for alignment or assistance pulling the card out (as my Banana Pro doesn't spring eject the card very well).  Also, there is no opening for the USB OTG port on the board which is covered up by the case.
comments.author: andyf101

comments.text:
I know about the audio port, but with my print it snapped nicely in place.
The tight enclosing of the sd-card is to protect it well, because it shouldn't be touched by mistake (hate those darn old raspberrys...). Had no problem accessing it, as my spring works well :-)
And the USB OTG is covered because I don't need it.
comments.author: andyf101

comments.text: Thanks for the quick response and model update!  The v2 models fit very well with the exposed OTG port and the easy to insert audio port opening.  My microSD card is spring ejecting better with use so the low clearance around that opening is working fine now.  I'm not using the IR sensor, but I suppose a note to others that this is covered.  There is a very slight gap where the two sides meet in the corner by ethernet port, this seems to be because the case is squeezing the ethernet port and that doesn't quite allow the case to close in that corner.  It's possible this is a result of warping or layer rounding - I printed it on a Replicator 2 with PLA using a layer height of 0.20 and no rafts/supports.  This is a great slim fitting enclosure for the Banana Pro, thanks again for sharing it!

author: PacificiValerio

description.text:
Some times I need the ability to mount an axle at the end of a rod. Slip this thing onto the end of a rod and you can then put an axle through the separated holes. This is a nice piece to help form a swivel joint between two different rods. The default size fits a rod with an outer diameter (OD) of 11.34mm (some carbon fiber tubing). The holes where an axle would go through can accept 1/4". These are easily configurable in the OpenScad file. UPDATE: 11022011
Changed the file slightly to have a better taper at the top.

1) Select a bore hole size for your rod
2) Alter the OpenScad file to match
3) Print some of these out
4) Slip a dowel pin of the appropriate size into the open holes
5) Hook something interesting onto the axle.
6) Rejoice!

author: lew597

description.text:
This is a remix of an existing extruder fan mount (see remixes) that   
didn't fit the simple 1405 and that had a tendency to fall off.  
I cleaned up the geometry (removing some of the extra vectors), removed some material that was preventing it from fitting on the 1405, and added some additional material to give it more traction when gripping the printer.  
This is a friction mount so make sure you press it on well or it will fall off.  
Update - I used up some of the extra space next to the z probe to increase the friction mount surface area.  It should stay on better now.

author: Intense_Customs

title: Printrbot Simple 1405 Fan Shroud for E3D v6 Hotend

description.text:
This fan shroud is optimised for use on the Prinrbot Simple 1405 with an E3D v6 Hotend. In theory it also works with the Ubis, however I can not guarantee, that it lines up correctly. There is a normal version (redone) available that works on the same principle as the original printrbot-shroud.
The other version (redone deflector) has a ring of material that goes all the way around the hotend. It doesn't look like much, but I have found that this makes quite a dramatic difference in airflow direction. It even prints without supports; thats tested with the cheapest PLA that was available. Just watch out, when heating your bed above ~60°C with the hotend close to it and the cooling fan not running, the deflector might sag down onto the bed. For a more advanced, omnidirectional version, check out this thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:655807

description.text:
Centered on Vroman's Nose, with Middleburg, NY in the upper right in the painted version. 
Created using a free program called Maperitive, which downloads elevation data from the open street map project. I then import the models into sketchup and do some post processing in meshlab and netfabb. 
As shown printed in ABS and painted by my friend Alex.

comments.text: Re: Damm31, I import the dae file from maperitive to sketchup, scale it, use the free stl exporter plugin, to export to stl, then usually refine the mesh and then take it back into sketchup to add the base and make it watertight, sometimes I scale it or check for watertightness in netfabb. Some geography seems to be better quality than other areas, so sometimes it works better than others. Also, sketchup will balk at handling too many faces, so large areas of terrain can be difficult and slow.

remixed_from.author: muckychris
remixed_from.title: Fan mounts for Flashforge, CTC & Makerbots

title: PLA Cooling Fan Mount - FlashForge and Powerspec

description.text:
I took muckychris' design and remade it from scratch. I printed his object and noticed that it didn't fit my Powerspec 3d Pro / FlashForge Creator / Creator Pro properly. The screw did not line up and the length of the top piece was too short. I also did not like the fan grills as it made it more difficult to print. My tolerances are tighter as well, and this is done by design to reduce the vibrations that the fans create. The less wiggle room inside the mount the fewer vibrations. Lastly, I increased the tilt a bit to get more air flow coverage. The tilt is now at 10 degrees.   
If you don't have cooling in place you will need to print this with supports, most likely it will fail without. If you have adequate cooling you might be able to skate by with only supports for the top piece.   
Note: In the gallery when I printed mine, the left side got slightly messed up due to miscalibration on my part so I'm in the process of re-printing.   
EDIT: When I uploaded the STL file it somehow comes out rotated. You need to print with the bracket / screw thread on the top. Print in the orientation as you see in the gallery.

• Import to your favorite slicer (I used Simplify3d)
  • Make sure you include proper supports if you do not have cooling (and even if you do it might be a good idea on some spots).
  • Print.
  • Mount at the top and center of your printer using the existing screw as shown in the gallery.
  • You will need to buy 2x 80mm x 25mm case fans from your favorite store, I used microcenter.
  • You will need a 12V AC to DC adapter, and connect the fans in parallel.
  • Profit from much improved prints.
    • EDIT: When I uploaded the STL file it somehow comes out rotated. You need to print with the bracket / screw thread on the top. Print in the orientation as you see in the gallery.

author: Plantsoen23

title: Violet the Train - Custom Train Faces
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Are you sick of the weird faces on your kid's toy trains?  Why not replace them with something cooler (or maybe weirder?)
3D Prints of their own faces!  
I tried this out for my nephew's 4th birthday.  He LOVES trains, and he lives far away from the rest of the family.  So I thought it might be a good idea to bring his cousins to him in Train form.  
I used the Thomas Wooden Railroad trains for this, but I'm sure you can just as easily do it with one of the other brands.

• Purchase a train that fits the tracks that the child you are purchasing for is using. I have girls, so I did not know that the trains are not 'one size fits all tracks'.

  • Remove the face. The Thomas Wooden Railroad faces are attached with two pins at 3:00 and 9:00, or just under the eyes on most trains. You can just drill or dremel them out or you can walk an exacto in if you want to keep the face. Once you've removed the pins, the tab at the bottom just pops out pretty easily.

  • Measure the diameter of the face and the width of the shelf at the top of the cattle catcher.

  • Obtain a scan of the subject child's face. You can scan them if they will sit still long enough. Probably not going to happen with most little kids unless you scan them in their sleep. I used Photo2Mesh to convert a photo to a raised 3D image.

  • Create another model that is a cylinder with a mounting flat on the bottom. I've attached an stl that works with Thomas, Charlie, and Rosie. I'm an Alibre user, so my parametric model probably won't be useful to many.

  • Use the cylinder shape to slice the face model.

  • Boolean the face model to the cylinder shape.

  • Print it. You're probably going to want to try to hit at least 80 microns. 50 microns is ideal. I have to admit, I had a heck of a time getting this to print and you can see that it is messed up at the bottom. I ended up merging the whole thing with a very thin cylinder and printing the first layers really slow.

  • Glue to train face. I printed mine in ABS. Acetone worked great.

  • Present to child and watch their face light up : )

comments.text: I'm going to take disturbing as a compliment?  I'd say these trains with faces are disturbing as-is.    I remember being watching late night b-movies as a teenager and they would show commercials for the trains (no idea why they used that time slot) and we would say they were scarier than the movies.

title: Air Vent - with easy removal hole.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I created this air vent to fill some unsightly holes.  It is sized for a 2" hole.  The tabs flex perfectly to give a good snug fit for a hole made by a 2" hole saw.  Also, the hole in the middle makes very easy removal with 1 finger.  
You can successfully scale down to .75 for a 1.5" hole.  Any lower and the lip might not cover the outside of the hole, but it's a quick print so you could definitely try a 1" hole.  
Should be able to upscale as much as you want.  At default size, it prints in about 20 minutes with my settings.  
P.S. - I could probably create an alternate hole pattern if someone has a specific request.

I printed successfully with:
  • .2 layer height with .35 first layer.
  • 10% infill (give or take, since it's so small a lot will be solid)
    • No brims, or supports needed.

UPDATE. Now will work with any thickness material, just edit scad file. Simple and sturdy. Takes reasonably large dice. Can be made out of acrylic or plywood. ~3mm cardboard works great too. Completed design will be decorated with Battletech tables engravings.
Tower shown in pictures is a full size mockup, it will be remade from acrylic when design is fully complete.

My acrylic turned out to be 0.11" rather than 0.13, so I just redesigned it in OpenSCAD to make it parametric.
New files -
007 - scad version - lets you to choose your material thickness and then export to svg or dxf. (to avoid scaling issues save as dxf and then follow an old instruction below)
008 - my design ready to cut with 0.11" acrylic.
009 - same as 008 but in svg so you can tinker with it. Instructions below are outdated. Included are 3 files: dwg was made in DraftSight and is the source file for the project; dxf was saved as intermediate to be opened with Inkscape; pdf is ready to lasercut with Epilog Mini 24 laser (assuming you are okay with plain design).
To add stuff for engraving:
  • Open dxf file with Inkscape
  • Make sure "Use automatic scaling to A4" is disabled and "Manual scaling factor" is set to 25.4
  • When imported, set units to inches and canvas size to your laser cutter size (24x12 in my case)
  • Select imported objects and ungroup them.
  • Select all, set line color to black and line width to 0.001"
  • Add your design for engraving where desired
  • Save result as pdf
  • Lasercut the project
  • Assemble together using glue

title: Leadnut adapter for RoBo 3D trapezoidial Z-axis threads Tr8x1.5

description.text:
This is a mod that allows you to change the Z-axis threads (either imperial or standard metric) to trapezoidial threads (from https://hfbshop.de/, german only -- sorry).
As those rods come with nuts that have a a 17mm wrench size you'll need this adapter to make it fit in the 13mm holes of the X-Z axis brackets. NOTE: Depending on what your previous rods were (e.g. M8x1.25), you'll need to adjust the steps per mm in your firmware, otherwise your objects will be too large in Z direction.
M8x1.25 has 1.25mm Z per rotation while the Tr8x1.5 has 1.5mm.
This also should have an effect on the layer height that you're using in your slicer. I usually use either 0.09, 0.12 or 0.21. These are the layer heights without Z rounding errors. Check Josef Prusa's calculor page.

You must print this upside down!
Duplicate it, you need 2 of them.
You should use brim to print unless you have a very sticky build plate!
It fits fairly tight but that's by intend. You don't want to introduce more gaps with this, otherwise you could run with the ootb rods :-)

A stripped down basic "case" for Raspberry Pi. 
Iâ€™m using this Pi as a development platform, and didnâ€™t want to print a bulky case for it. I couldnâ€™t find anything that fit what I was looking for so I designed this. It allows the Pi to be moved around easily without touching the board and contacts, and raises it off the ground about 6mm.

Print the 2 sides, composite and hdmi, then press onto the corresponding side on your Raspberry Pi. It will be snug and take some pressure get it to snap on, be gentle.
The corners at the end of the internal slots round off a bit during printing, and may need to be cleaned out with an x-acto to get it to fit.
These are very snug on my Pi. Iâ€™m not sure of the tolerances on the boards, but Iâ€™ve attached step files if anyone needs to change the openings slightly.
I printed at 10% infill, 2 shells, and .2mm layer height.

comments.text: Perfect! Love the minimal design, works great as printed, and just what I was looking for!

The base is now 3mm thick, the horn is also thicker - stronger, and the nut hole has been enlarged to accept an easier to find 4-40 nut. This doesn't leave a lot of 'meat' around the nut, so I put very-VERY small dabs of gel CA on each side, before pressing the nut into place. This will add strength, and also make the nut a part of the piece, so if cracking does occur, it shouldn't just fall apart. Enjoy!
I printed mine at 100% infill. THe weight difference is negligible, but the increase in strength is significant. Use as many perimeters as you want, since printing 100%, it doesn't really matter.

In this project we’re building a handheld gaming console! This DIY gadget has 12 buttons, an analog joystick, stereo speakers and a 5” HDMI display. We’re using the Raspberry Pi A+ and RetroPie image. We call it.... Super Game Pi! Bigger than our DIY GameBoy, this project has support for way more games, a bigger screen, sound and all ze buttons! To make your own Super Game Pi, you’ll have to 3D print the enclosure, hack an SNES controller and solder electronics. You can pick the Raspberry Pi A+ and all the parts to build this project from Adafruit. We’ll need some hand tools and access to a 3D Printer. Check out the full tutorial
https://learn.adafruit.com/super-game-pi Adafruit invests time and resources providing this open source design, please support Adafruit and open-source hardware by purchasing products from Adafruit! Designed by Noe and Pedro for Adafruit Industries.
Creative Commons 2.5, attribution share-alike.
All text above must be included in any redistribution.

Features Components:
• Raspberry Pi A+
• True 5” HDMI Display w/ TFP401 Display Driver
• Analoy joystick + 6 Buttons
• 66000mAh Lithium Ion Battery
• Powerboost500 Charger
• Stereo Audio

title: Customizable Curved Beams for LEGO Technic

description.text: Here are different curved beams that work with LEGO Technic. Print a bunch of these, connect them with small LEGO pins and see what kind of designs you can create! For the photos, I used twelve 9 hole parts. Using the same beams I also created stop motion animations that can be viewed here: https://vimeo.com/118086832 and https://vimeo.com/119009532 I've included several designs that you can easily print. In the file name, the first number is the number of holes and the second is the angle between adjacent holes. This angle determines the radius of the beam. You can also use the Customizer to make your own beams. Just enter the number of holes and the degrees between holes. The number of degrees sets the radius of the beam. Experiment with these settings to get a sense of the design possibilities. You can even make a complete circle. Or you can download the OpenSCAD file and tweak all of the parameters directly. Because of the way I wrote the programmed, the generation of the 3D solid part may take a few minutes.

Designed in OpenSCAD, sliced in Simplify3D, printed on a MakerBot Replicator2 with Elmer's Craft Bond glue stick on a glass build plate with PushPlastic filament and the following settings: Infill = 20%
Layer height = 0.2
No. shells = 4
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220C No support is needed.

author: stevemedwin

description.text:
I was inspired by Zampik to design something non-mechanical.
The shapes interest me, and I was interested to figure out how to create similar shapes in Helix Modeling (MicroCadam circa 2000).
I used an intersection of two solids. Took me awhile to get it and the program choked on my more outrageous ones. I printed this one "fast" out of ABS using .3mm layers. I took about 2.5 hours. I do not usually use a fan on ABS but I used 50% on this on because I did not use support, and some of the vanes were not cooling fast enough in the first 25 layers. After that, I turned the fan off. Used Simplify3d. Hard to make the leap because of cost, but I am now glad I did!
I will probably try it in clear PLA or ABS next. Makes it look good in a window.
Try stretching + and - to get some different effects. I added another vase, #7. I will take awhile to print. Like about 3 hours and 45 min. Added vase8A which should print faster than vase8 and has a different curve and transition towards the top. It was meant to replace the original, but I decided they both have virtues.

description.text:
An improvement on Rocket #1, splitting the fuselage into top and bottom halves and adding legs and an engine. All are printed separately for maximum size.  
I have been using this as a Christmas gift and calibration print for switching to Simplify3D (from RepG). The glow-in-the-dark PLA is my favorite since in addition to glowing it is translucent and the infill gives it a cool texture.

All parts are intended to be printed with no support. (The model for the bottom half will work best flipped.)  
The legs press fit nicely for me printed at 95% scale and engine fits with no scaling, but YMMV. Top and bottom will need to be glued together.

This is a model of the structure of human cytochrome C. The model is based on the solution structure and the PDB file 1J3S.  
This printed well, and is now a completed model. I have painted it and provided some pictures.  
This protein is the human version, and is important for the transfer of electrons in the electron transport chain. It has a single heme heteroatom, which I have represented as CPK, along with the histidine ligand. I was a little bit upset by how flimsy it was following the initial print, but actually have grown to like it very much, as it gives one the sense of the fluidity of the protein backbone and structure. It is not as sturdy as some of my other models, but turned out very nice.

This structure is an extensive print. THIS CAN ONLY BE PRINTED WITH SUPPORT selected in Makerware, and a word of warning, expect 2-3 hours to remove the support and get down to the actual model. I removed the supports as well, and have painted it. I am printing at medium quality. The build time was nearly 8 hours, so be warned, it takes some time. This model is somewhat fragile, so take your time removing the support. I use a pair of needlenose pliars to break off the support structure slowly, and remove the support from the remaining model. I printed this out on a Makerbot Replicator 2.  
The model took a good deal of effort to construct. The original pdb file (1J3S) was manipulated until only the single monomer with no water molecules was included. This was then placed into the program VMD. I manipulated the backbond as cartoons, and then selected the histidine ligand and heme for display as CPK, and added some bonds to serve as supports to hold the structure together (these are somewhat flimsy). This was then imported in several segments into tinkercad (tinkercad had a problem importing files larger than 20 Mb, so I had to import and then align as three components. I then grouped and aligned everything, and added a number of manual support features at the bottom. The smaller braces are designed to be removed, while the larger braces hold the model together. I did break a small section at the end of the molecule at one point, which I had to glue along with one of the supports for the heme. These glued well with standard model glue.  
If you do choose to print this out, be prepared for a significant level of work, and be patient removing the supports, but the print is very nice. I painted the alpha helices in orange and the beta sheets in teal, and also painted the individual atoms of the heme and histidine ligand. The iron was painted green.

It is a little too detailed to try to explain how I do this here. If you send me an e-mail, I can send you some more detailed instructions on what I do.

description.text:
Device to identify bolts and nuts by size. SAE sizes from #4 up to 1/2, with customizable openscad file. There are ruler tic-marks along one edge for measuring bolt lengths.  
After printing you will need the following to populate it: (1) 3/4" x #4 machine screw and (2) #4 nuts. Ditto for #6, #8, #10. Then (1) nut and (1) bolt each for 1/4, 5/16, 3/8, 7/16, and 1/2. Glue in the bolts and nuts, taking care to put them in the proper columns as shown in the picture, because bolt head sizes occasionally differ from the sizes of their matching nuts.   
Bolts of the same diameter can come with different thread counts, so either pick the thread you use most for each size, or make 2 of these gizmos to cover both coarse and fine threads.  
You can also fill in the lettering and the ruler tics with caulk of a contrasting color to your plastic. I had more luck with this if I inverted my original print in the z direction so the 'lettered' surface printed smooth, making it easier to cleanly wipe off excess caulk.

After printing you will need the following to populate it: (1) 3/4" x #4 machine screw and (2) #4 nuts. Ditto for #6, #8, #10. Then (1) nut and (1) bolt each for 1/4, 5/16, 3/8, 7/17, and 1/2. Pick bolt lengths to your taste.  
Bolts of the same diameter can come with different thread counts, so either pick the thread you use most for each size, or make 2 of these gizmos to cover both course and fine threads.  
Glue in the bolts and nuts with hot glue or silicone, or heat them up and weld them to your plastic. Take care to put them in the proper columns as shown in the picture, because bolt head sizes occasionally differ from the sizes of their matching nuts.  
You can also fill in the lettering and the ruler tics with caulk of a contrasting color to your plastic. I had more luck with this if I inverted my original print in the z direction so the 'lettered' surface printed smooth, making it easier to cleanly wipe off excess caulk.

author: fiid

title: Open source 60cm or 120cm rotor diameter Wind Turbine

description.text:
This is a little wind turbine. It can be printed at 100% scale or 54%.
See instructions for more details.

This is a worl-in-progress please double check all parts before you start with the assembling.  
I will really appreciate any feedback  
Scale 100%  (to be tested)

• N 4 - 626-2Z bearings for the full scale
  • N 2 - bolt 6mmx130mm
  • N x - washer and nut
  • N 12 - Coils. I plan to use the OMRON LY2 110VDC Relais coils.
    • Scale 54% ( 1 Done )

I did not plan power generation for the small scale.
  • N 4 - 4 623-2Z
  • N 2 - bolt 3mmx70mm
  • N x - washer and nut
  • N 1 - 60cm rod. I used graphene rod 10mm ext 3 mm int.
  • N 9 - 1mmx4mm self-tapping screw
    Some plywood 1,5mm thick for the wind blades.
    • Blades

From the plywood cut 3 isosceles trapezoid.
15mm small side (top)
39mm long side (bottom)
3000mm height Tail

1 isosceles trapezoid.
7cm small side
17cm long side
11cm height Tail supports

2 rectangles
16cm long side
12mm small side !! double check this measure !! Those rectangle must be placed on the middle of the Tail and stickout from the short size of about 2/3 of their size. Print tips.

The body (corpo) must be rotated with the bottom bearing hole facing the print plane. I suggest to add, then,  a 15° angle and a bottom cut of 1mm.  
The mozzo must be rotated with the plane face facing the print plane.  
The tappo must be rotated with the bigger plane face facing the print plane.  
Settings

For my prototype i used
0.8mm nozzle
0.3 layer
0.8mm thin wall
13% infill Future
The upper cap is only a "stub" it misses holes and engraves.

description.text:
This is either a brilliant idea or a TERRIBLE one.
This doesn't need to print perfectly to work, it just needs to be sturdy and still have some degree of ridging on the inner wheel.
Oh and the flat might need to be shrunk a bit.

The Stepstruder MK6 is a huge leap forward for stepper driven extrusion.  We've searched high and low to find a high torque NEMA17 stepper motor that is capable of direct driving 3mm filament.  Using a direct drive extruder means that there is absolutely no backlash from gears.  Not only that, but this spells an end to the days of DC gearmotors that are unreliable and have short lifetimes.  Stepper motors effectively last forever, and these motors will provide you with thousands of hours of 3D printing awesomeness.

Full instructions at: http://wiki.makerbot.com/stepstruder-mk6
or
Buy the complete kit online at: http://store.makerbot.com/stepstruder-mk6.html
Or the kit to upgrade your existing MK5: http://store.makerbot.com/stepstruder-mk6-upgrade.html

title: Daniel Tiger's Neighborhood Trolley
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The trolley we purchased for our set of Daniel Tiger figures was annoying my daughter because it wasn't big enough for all five characters to ride. SO, I put this one together... but keep in mind my printer is only 150x150 so it has to be very modular. When put together, the trolley is around 285mm long and 145mm tall. Everything comes apart, and is meant to be printed separately in whatever colors you like, and then put assembled. You will need to glue stuff. Also, feel free to get different wheels... this just a stopgap until I find some actual hobby wheels and axles that are more sturdy. Finally, if you want to go for authenticity, try printing the side cars with yellow for the first 3mm and then switch to red for the last 2mm. It'll give you the two-toned look in the render. (If you have a dual extruder... solve your own problems ;) If you want other DT playsets for your figures, I made a royal castle also! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:624561

title: Logitech C270 Camera Mount for 20mm Extrusions

description.text: The Logitech C270 is an awesome camera for Octoprint/Pi setups. This is a simple mount that uses part of the C270's clamp as the "tilt" and the mount swivels for the "pan".

The mount is held together with a 4-40 flat-head screw and a washer between the camera mount and base. I printed this one with ABS at 0.3mm LH and 50% infill.  
Depending on how close the camera is to the subject of interest, the C270 may need to be refocused (not hard) which is not covered here but instructions can be easily found on the internet.

author: kloberujo

description.text:
All parts modified, relevant printing limits/fits applied, Printed,
assembled and working.
Case cut down from original 'work in progress' to reduce print time and aid viewing https://youtu.be/8ibiVU4RxOU

All PLA cold bed, 210 extrude, rafts and support where needed
Minimum finishing of parts required

I needed a dry box that would hold two large spools (1 kg). First I needed a clear plastic box which I bought from Target (see photo of label).
I tried several spool rollers but did not like the design of any so I made my own. Next was to get the filament out of the box but this time I found a good design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:318580) but had to make a change to the top cap to have a tight fit on the 6mm tube that the FlashForge Creator Pro uses. Next I needed a desiccant box for the indicating desiccant that I use so once again I made my own. I also wanted to identify what type of filament was on each roller so I created some tags that fit the box. I glued magnets to the lid and labels so they remained in place. So you so you don't have to go running all over the place I will provide all the parts that I used. I made two large spool rollers. The bearings, rod and shaft collars and aluminum tube I ordered from the large online retailer Am*$on (Amazon), because I am lazy. Like I said before the box I got from Target.
You need: (1) 8 Bearings 608ZZ 8x22x7 pre-greased
(2) 8mm shaft 30"
(3) Aluminum 6061-T6 Seamless Round Tubing, WW-T 700/6, 1" OD, 0.87" ID, 0.065" Wall,
(4) 4 or 8 8mm ID Shaft Collars (one or two spool rollers)
(5) Two inside parts for the filament caps http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:318580 and the top cap with my mod. I have included the lower part of 318580 so you don't have to go looking around
(7) a desiccant box of your choice (I have included one above)
(8) a plastic box that seals well (see photo of what I used)

I created this Ryobi ONE+ battery holder after seeing one created by MichaelAtOz.  I started from scratch with a new OpenSCAD program so this design is not based on MichaelAtOz's design.  This version has a tighter fit, larger mounting hole (for a concrete screw), and thinner body.  I have included STL files for the holder, the wedge, and a combined STL with the holder and wedge.

I recommend printing this solid (90% fill) with  thick shells.  Because the holder is 1.5mm thick this won't use much material.  My build on a da Vinci 1.0 used ~5 meters of 1.75mm filament. If you want the electrical connection openings from sagging on top you may want to add supports.  Since the supports will only be in the 3 openings it shouldn't waste much material.

comments.text: Hi, did you try my Thing, what was the problem that lent you to redesign?
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: I didn't use your thing because it was too loose and I didn't easily see how to change this in your OpenSCAD file.  I did print one and I didn't want to scale it outside of OpenSCAD.  My OpenSCAD file has 6 variables to create the body which easily scale.  I added a Margin variable to change the fit which was too snug at 1.00 (no margin), too loose at 1.05 (5% margin), and just right at 1.01 (1% margin).  Also I really just enjoy creating objects that I find useful!  I am new to OpenSCAD so it was helpful to create a relatively complex object.
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

title: Rocket Fin Can for 29mm body tube

description.text: I have flown this several times past Mach 1 since the fins are perfectly aligned every time. All you have to do is print it (10% fill, normal speed print, with rafts) and epoxy the fin can a quarter-inch or so above the bottom (so you can use a ring of duct tape for motor retention) of a 12" (or longer) strong body tube (it is perfectly sized for Blue Tube) and tape a golf ball to the top (range balls are free nose cone + weight, which you will need). If you have extra epoxy, lather it on the fins for a smooth finish and extra strength. The launch rod lugs and fin fillets are built into the print. Ready to fly in 5 minutes with single use Aerotech motors (I use the H135 or H195 to go supersonic, but for those without Level 1 Certs, you can fly the G-motors just fine). Launch photos: https://www.flickr.com/search/?text=3d%20print%20rocket&sort=date-posted-desc&user_id=44124348109%40N01 Here is a talk I gave on 3D-printing and rocketry at MakerFaire: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IBMMPBpZeHo Blue Tube supplier: http://www.alwaysreadyrocketry.com/about-us/blue-tube-2-0/

So you so you don't have to go running all over the place I will provide all the parts that I used. I made two large spool rollers. The bearings, rod and shaft collars and aluminum tube I ordered from the large online retailer Am*$on (Amazon), because I am lazy. You need: (1) 8 Bearings 608ZZ 8x22x7 pre-greased
(2) 8mm shaft 30"
(3) Aluminum 6061-T6 Seamless Round Tubing, WW-T 700/6, 1" OD, 0.87" ID, 0.065" Wall,
(4) 4 or 8 8mm ID Shaft Collars After printing the STL for either a single or dual, cut the aluminum tubing just a little shorter than the inside measurement of the Spool Holder but tight enough so the edge of a spool can fall into. Next take a bearing and clean the outer edge. Take some clear Scotch Tape and make one turn around the outside (see photos). This serves as a shim and also to keep super glue out of the bearing. Next use some gap filling (thick) super glue and run a small bead around the inside of the aluminum tube. Fold or taper the Scotch Tape so you can insert the bearing without getting glue on the bearing. Push bearing in, just flush or just protruding a little if you have the room. Do all tubes the same way then leave overnight to let the glue dry. Assemble by cutting the 8mm shaft to the correct length (don’t forget to add the length of two collars).
Assemble and use.

author: sdfreiberger

title: E3D-V6 mount for the BI V2.5

description.text:
Laser cut out of 6mm Baltic Birch Ply.
The groove mount is simply press fit in the BI V2.5 original effector.
The support bolts in the factory holes and backs up the hot end and further secures it. The E3D-V6 is very secure with this. No play, no wobble. It hangs below the effector which clears the fan mount completely.

For the groove mount, cut out the blank first. It's just a square cut in half. Once cut, press the 2 halves together taking care not to move the bottom part. Then, cut the actual mount. That will eliminate the laser kerf and give you a tighter, press fit.

You can always use Tosh's design if you want to use 4x6 photos. In the future, I might adjust my dimensions better for 4x6 photos, but we'll see.   
You may even want to use 3 or 4 of these holders for larger photos to keep them more secure.

author: sdfreiberger

title: Integrated Fin Can for supersonic flights on 38mm minimum-diameter rockets

description.text: I have flown this several times to Mach 1.9 (according to RockSim) since the fins are perfectly aligned every time. All you have to do is print it (10% fill, normal speed print, with rafts) and epoxy the fin can a quarter-inch or so above the bottom (so you can use a ring of duct tape for motor retention) of a 18" (or longer) strong 38mm motor/body tube (it is perfectly sized for Blue Tube) and tape a golf ball to the top (range balls are free nose cone + weight, which you will need). If you have extra epoxy, lather it on the fins for a smooth finish and extra strength. The launch rod lugs, rail guides (which I highly recommend for rigidity) and fin fillets are built into the print. Ready to fly in 5 minutes with single use Aerotech motors (I have flown the J270, I140 and I280 to go supersonic). Launch photos: https://www.flickr.com/search/?text=3d%20print%20rocket&sort=date-posted-desc&user_id=44124348109%40N01 Here is a talk I gave on 3D-printing and rocketry at MakerFaire: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IBMMPBpZeHo Blue Tube supplier: http://www.alwaysreadyrocketry.com/about-us/blue-tube-2-0/ For 38mm flights, I also add a cheap aluminum GLR rail guide to the upper part of the motor/body tube (don’t use a rod for I or J motors; when I did, it snapped two legs off of my Aerotech Mantis launch pad, laying it flat! That’s some serious whiplash!): https://giantleaprocketry.com/products/components_launch_systems.aspx#Acme_Conformal_Launch_Guides Single use Aerotech motors (can only be sold to people with Level 1 or Level 2 certification): http://www.wildmanrocketry.com/ShowProducts.aspx?Class=82&Sub=107&Sub1=118

author: sycon

description.text: porta bobina laterale x Da Vinci

After seeing Allan's "*sta" post on the Thingiverse blog[1], I couldn't help but actually make the "star-sta" a reality. This is technically a derivative of yzorg's Gangsta[2], but since I haven't actually printed it, I don't feel right clicking "I Made One". Thanks to tbuser for his 2D to 3D tutorial[3] which has the right pstoedit voodoo required to export things sanely from Inkscape to OpenSCAD. Thanks to Inkscape for having a Star tool. Thanks to MCAD for the oval generation code.[4] Thanks to OpenSCAD for making ridiculous things like this possible. Thanks to cibomahto for creating this mash-up madness. [1] *sta - http://blog.thingiverse.com/2011/02/10/sta/
[2] Gangsta by yzorg - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5367
[3] 2D to 3D - http://tonybuser.com/2d-to-3d
[4] MCAD - https://github.com/elmom/MCAD

Want your own *sta?
  • Scale.
  • Skein.
  • 'sta.
    • If you'd like to tweak the model, you'll also need the gangsta.stl from yzorg's Gangsta (linked above), then:
  • 'SCAD.
  • Scale.
  • Skein.
  • 'sta.

description.text: A basic case for 4" speakers. Cut with 1/8" thick wood. There is a small rectangular hole in the back for wires to come out of. The speakers are held in with 10-24 pan head screws that are 3/8" long and the matching nuts. Speakers used: http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/GF1004/GF1004-ND/304447

This was made for a class project at the last minute, with a laser cutter I just finished putting together and calibrating. To save time I made the slots for the tabs slightly wider than necessary so I wouldn't possibly cut ones that were too small. I used some hot glue on the inside of the box to hold it together, although this wouldn't be needed if you used thicker material. If I magically get free time I can maybe go back and edit the files, or if someone asks.
First test with dual extruder on Flashforger dreamer. Don't forget to set the distance between the extruders in the On Board Settings!
Flashforge dreamer at 60mm/s, 220 degrees white ABS, 210 degrees blue PLA, 105 degrees print bed.

This is a mounting fixture for a Harbor Freight dial gage indicator. Use it to attach to a RepRap G3D (Prusa i3 design from Gadgets3D) x-axis printer rails to simplify the bed leveling process.  The design uses a latch to simplify attachment and help improve measurement repeatability.  
Attaches to 8mm diameter rails with 45mm center spacing.
SketchUp files are included.  Slic3r was used to generate G-code.
2016-01-23 Update:  Cleaned up Sketchup file.

remixed_from.title: Flat Case for RAMPS 1.4 Mix & Match Edition

remixed_from.author: Yvan
remixed_from.title: Case Bottom for RAMPS 1.4 - No Clamps!

description.text:
This wire box is derived from the flat box for RAMPS designed by Yvan. My idea is to create a similar box below the RAMPS box that houses all of the cables and has access on the left and right sides.
I am simply inverting the box ( flipping it upside down ) and using sides that have cable chain connector holes. For the Female connection, simply insert a regular chain link, with the male side from out of the box to inside, then superglue the connector in place. The Original Cable Chain this is remixed from is
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978

Left side: Cable tie holes on the left of the part, Cable chain connection at the bottom of the part.   
Right side  Cable tie holes on the right of the part, Cable chain connection at the bottom of the part.   
Bottom:   
Back Plate: (drill your own holes based upon your frame design)  
Door: Use 4 cable ties to attach door   
Super glue all parts except the door together  
Designed to house all wires leaving an opening to the open bottom of the RAMPS case.  Door not required to open as just housing cables, so is closed by cable ties and if you need to go into it cut then replace cable ties.

description.text: A frige game you can play with your food !!! You can get the magnets here there cheap enough. http://www.magnet4sale.com/lot-10-n42-neodymium-magnets-dia-3-8x1-10-ndfeb-epoxy-coated/
Snap in Magnets You might need Super Glue I didn't but just in case also Gobb Stoppers Are around the Same size as Marbles But Not as Fun to eat....
Uses 2x 608ZZ bearings and either 5/8" bolt or 8mm rod. Tension is provided by two 0.5in ceramic disc magnets.  Other screws are M3 and the knob uses M2.5.

comments.text: Half inch magnets won't fit into formed depressions, requires 12 mm magnets (available in Canada from Dollar Tree). Magnets must be installed so the two in back attract, and the two in front repel. I used 4-40 screws and nuts, although for finger piece screw I used a 2.6 mm. I used a 5/16 inch stove bolt (threaded over entire length) that was about 1-1/2 inches too long; after installing with nuts (with nylon bushings), I cut off the excess length (the bolt head end) with a hacksaw. This key works really well (needs heavy base added), almost feels as good as my Bencher RJ-2 key.
comments.author: ve3rrd

comments.text: I think you mean a 5/16" bolt for the middle pivot, not a 5/8". You might also consider enlarging the bearing holes a little. They print with interference and I had to open them up with some sandpaper. Otherwise a good design!

A baby Ultimaker Original, as an hommage to the real thing. It has 5 pieces and can be printed without support! Both the blue print and some of the renders as you can see are not in the right proportions. I fixed it in the download files. Photo's of grey model with teddy bear are made by Ultimaker themselves. All the other non-ugly-blue prints are from the Ultimaker design competition on https://ultimaker.com/en/community/18427-community-contest-part-5-the-tribute . If you make one, please share the results!

The parts should fit together without having to glue them. You might need to file down some connections to make it fit (depending on the quality of your print).  
The top part is printed upside-down, the rest speaks for itself.  
It can be a bit of a challenge for your printer, so fiddle with your settings. There are some small wall thicknesses, a bit of overhang and a chance of warping. Nothing a well-tweaked Ultimaker can't handle though!  
The filament holes are 2mm. I couldn't find a suitable wire for that myself, but there are probably 2mm electricity wires that will fit. I used a green binding string, which works quite okay.

title: iPhone 6 Plus Holder/Mount/Dock for GPS (naked and with cases)

description.text:
Here is an iPhone 6 Plus mount/holder/dock that can be glued to a GPS system such as the ("Any Car Phone) "Any Car Phone Dock" by azzeloof or "CD Slot iPhone Holder" by polygoo. Each STL file is for a different purpose: +Naked iPhone 6 Plus
+iPhone 6 Plus with an Agent18 Clear Case. (The clear case is 80mm wide and 9mm thick).
+iPhone 6 Plus with a CellBee Super Slim Hard Shell Case (The original case was measured to be 80.95mm wide x 10.25mm thick)

Notes:
The GPS mount for the Agent 18 Clear Case was designed from scratch, whereas the naked mount was designed based off of davidmus' "iPhone 6 Plus Stand" UPDATE
iPhone 6 Plus Phone Mount (Agent18 Case) v2.stl
+slimmer design (thickness of the material is now 2mm instead of 4mm), slightly wider measurements make it easier to slide the phone in and out while still providing a secure/snug fit.

Print with your preferred print settings. No raft or supports required. I used MakerBot Desktop's PLA LOW Resolution (Fastest) settings:
0.3mm layer height
10% infill
2 shells

description.text: This is a chopper wheel for optical and optoelectronic experiments. This component is part of the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware: by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

This is a customizable chopper wheel -- derived from the very nice ---Parametric encoder wheels and the shaft lock for wheels with a nut cage for mounting firmly to a spinning shaft from our less versatile Parametric open-source chopper wheel. It is a bit rough, could be made even more flexible and the OpenSCAD could used cleaned up a bit, but I leave that up to you. For a collection of open source optics see this This component is part of the Open-source Optics Library: Zhang C, Anzalone NC, Faria RP, Pearce JM (2013) Open-Source 3D-Printable Optics Equipment. PLoS ONE 8(3): e59840. This is part of a larger project to reduce the cost of scientific equipment using open-source hardware. Read more here

These files can create replacements for the Sphinx and Anubis game pieces from Khet 2.0. They are made to fit a Khet 1.0 game board, so this is basically an upgrade from 1.0 to 2.0.  
My photos only show the red pieces since I have some other things to print in red before I switch out to my silver filament.  
The build takes a little effort, so I'll put the build info in the instructions section. If you have any questions or find any mistakes, please leave a comment!  
I hope you enjoy it!

(Stuff to buy)
2x laser pointers (small cheap ones) $8
6x LR44 batteries $3 (for a pack of 10)
6x LR44 battery holders $4 (about) (Stuff I already had)
Soldering iron and solder
Wire
Hot glue gun and glue
3D printer with red and silver PLA (luckily already had both colors!)
Pliers
Hobby knife So I spent about $15 making a full upgrade set. (minus mistakes, more on that later)

First you'll need to find some mini laser pointers. I found some on Amazon. http://www.amazon.co.jp/gp/product/B00E5ZQX3E
I chose the 1 led, 1 laser combo key chain pointers because they seemed small. They run on LR41 batteries, which means I can substitute LR44s, which are easier to find for cheap and have easy to procure battery holders (at least for me). I picked those up at a local electronics parts store. Radio Shack would probably have this stuff if you can find a Radio Shack that actually carries parts and not just cell phones, but I digress. Second, print the Anubis replacement pieces as they are. I used a 20% fill for most of these upgrade pieces. The fins in the bottom of the base are there just for support, so you can remove them or leave them there. They're pretty easy to remove. Third, printing the front and back Sphinx replacement pieces requires a bit of rotating in your printing software. I use Cura and it's very easy to rotate. If you can't do it in your printer software, the SCAD file is available. Rotate the front and back pieces 90 degrees so that the inside cavities are facing up. This should prevent all overhangs and the need for any support material. The base and button I printed at 100% fill for stability. Fourth heat up your soldering iron, because it's time to prepare the laser pointers. Unscrew the back and remove the batteries. Pull the front cap off (if it's hard you can use pliers) and remove the laser assembly. Mine were wrapped in tape, so pull that off if it's there. Follow the circuit from the battery spring to the front button nearest the laser barrel. If you're using the same laser as mine, that's the negative terminal on the front button. You'll solder a black wire to that front button in a second. Now, desolder the LED, battery spring, and button furthest from the laser barrel and then cut off that bit of the circuit board. (my photo shows most of this) I used the wire cutter on my needle nose pliers to do this, then smoothed it out with a hobby knife. Fifth, mock up the battery holders in the printed base. Line them up so that it's easy to solder. If you look at the photo I included you'll see that I tried to line up the negative terminals to the positive terminals on the other holders. We are soldering in a series so that our 1.5 volt batteries combine to make 4.5 volts. Fill the gap between them with just enough hot glue to keep them together. They will fit snugly inside the base and may poke out of the top a bit at first, but that's why the body is recessed as well. When the glue hardens, remove the holders and using two pieces of wire (I use white for my series terminals), solder positive to negative on 2 different pairs of terminals. Essentially we are making the batteries touch front to back. If you're still not sure of what to solder by my description and picture, please google batteries in a series and learn a bit more before proceeding. You should now have 1 negative terminal and 1 positive terminal. Solder a black wire to the negative and a red wire to the positive. We're almost done. Sixth, combining the battery holders and the laser is pretty simple, but I learned some important points through trial and error. I'll let you in on the secrets to save you some cash and stress. Start off by soldering the black (negative) wire from the battery holders to the previously determined point on the button of the laser pointer. The positive terminal is the laser barrel itself. DO NOT solder to the laser barrel. It is made out of brass and it conducts heat VERY quickly. The focusing lens inside the barrel is plastic (along with the screw holding it in) and it will likely melt before the wire will affix to the barrel. I recommend simply pushing the positive wire under the barrel in the front half of the body. There is enough space and it should fit pretty snugly. You can use a bit of hot glue to fix it in place. The pieces are designed so that the laser barrel will poke out of the front of the body by 5-6 mm. However, before you go gluing lots of things in place, you will need to figure out exactly where things will line up. This alignment process is very important and will determine how many times the laser can bounce from mirror to mirror before it starts missing pieces altogether. I don't have much advice on this just yet, because I'm still working on it myself. I'm close, but I need to wait on another laser pointer to arrive before I can get it perfect. I tried to solder to the barrel twice (in different spots). The first time was a disaster with melted lens and screw. The second time I removed the lens and screw, but when I replaced them I somehow ended up with an elongated laser dot. Again, don't solder to the barrel. I think you should aim for hitting 6-7 mirrors without missing the 8th target. This is about the accuracy of the built-in board lasers. The mirrors on the game pieces are usually what cause the laser to deviate beyond that. Currently I can hit a target after about 4 mirror bounces. Not terrible, but not good enough for a regular game. Finally, after aligning everything, you can close up the body. I just put a bit of hot glue on the flat spaces between the two halves and quickly pushed them together, but you could use epoxy if you want more time to line things up. Same goes for the base, but it is important to make sure you have the laser square with the base. Otherwise you've wasted all your laser alignment time. Hot glue the battery holders to the bottom of the body and you should have enough clearance so that the batteries don't touch the game board. That's it! You're done! Enjoy your Khet 1.0 game set with the 2.0 rules! (I've tried to proof read all this and make it as clear as possible, but if you find any mistakes or have any questions, please leave them in the comment section.)
